awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Computational Faddeev approach to Nuclear Reactions
awd_abstract_narration:
Nuclear Science is tasked with answering questions such as: (i) How did matter come into being and how does it evolve? (ii) How does subatomic matter organize itself and what phenomena emerge? (iii) How can the knowledge and technology progress provided by nuclear physics best be used to benefit society? Providing answers to these questions depends on a detailed theoretical understanding of nuclear reactions, a field in which current approaches are either outdated or limited to a small number of applications. In this larger context, this project will focus on the theoretical study of deuteron-induced reactions. Due to the short lifetimes involving exotic nuclei, direct neutron capture measurements of relevance to the origin of the heavy elements are often not possible. Indirect techniques like deuteron induced reactions are a common tool to extract the relevant astrophysical rates. These reactions are part of ongoing experimental programs at radioactive beam facilities, as well as programs at future facilities such as the Facility for Rare Isotope Beams (FRIB). As such, this project will provide theoretical support to challenging experimental programs and will provide a unique training opportunity for graduate students and post-doctoral fellows.

A reliable reaction theory is critical for the understanding the data produced at experimental programs using (d,p) reactions. From a theoretical perspective, (d,p) reactions are attractive because the scattering can be reduced to an effective three-body problem. One of the most challenging aspects of solving the three-body problems for nuclear reactions is posed by the repulsive Coulomb interaction. While for light nuclei the momentum-space Faddeev equations can be treated by screening the Coulomb force, a similar approach is difficult to implement for heavy systems. Indeed, for most of the new exotic nuclei to be produced at FRIB, currently available computational methods are not adequate. This project will address this critical need and provide an implementation of an exact Faddeev method for the three-body nuclear reaction problem, in which the Coulomb force will be treated without screening.

por.por_cntn:
Motivated by learning about the properties of nuclei and extracting crucial information about reaction rates for astrophysics and other applications, researchers perform nuclear reactions in laboratories across the world. A specific class of reactions involves impinging a deuteron (consisting of a proton and a neutron) on the target of interest. From a theoretical approach, such reactions are most often approximated by a three-body scattering problem: (neutron+proton)+target.

 

Over the decades, much work has gone into establishing numerical techniques to solve the three-body scattering problem. Although the exact equations where introduced by Faddeev in the 1950s, there are considerable technical difficulties when the particles involved have charge, since theCoulomb force has infinite range. A group in Lisbon introduced a technique that involves screening of the Coulomb force and thus making it effectively finite range. While this technique has been successfully applied for reaction with light nuclei, it breaks down when applied to heavy nuclei.

 

When solving equations on a computer, one always must choose basis function in which those equations are expanded and numerically solved with. When expanding Faddeev equations in a basis given by Coulomb functions and the interactions between the particles in a separable basis, then one no longer needs to screen the Coulomb force in order to solve those Faddeev equations. Implementing this different and new approach and demonstrating its validity was the essence of this project consisting of a collaboration between Ohio University (PI Elster) and Michigan State University (PI Nunes).

 

First, the collaboration focused on implementing the new technique for bound states, which is somewhat easier than for scattering conditions. Calculations using this new framework were applied to the 6Li nucleus, which we considered as neutron+proton+4He composite system. Benchmarks with traditional methods showed that our approach converges to the same answer with very good accuracy. As additional bonus, we could show that the neutron+proton+4He composite system can be understood in terms of few-body universality and that the 6Li nucleus can be thought of as a two-nucleon halo nucleus, a property usually only associated with nuclei having a neutron halo.

 

Next the collaboration moved to implementing the formalism for scattering. Benchmark calculations of the new method for the scattering of deuterons from a 4He target demonstrated for a variety of different observables that the new method reproduces the screening method of the Lisbon group.

 

This project supported the postdoctoral researcher Jin Lei at Ohio University (OU) and the graduate student Alaina Ross at Michigan State University (MSU). This collaborative effort was leveraged with a contribution from MSU that supported the postdoc Linda Hlophe MSU.

The suite of codes resulting from this project can be made publicly available upon request.

 

This project impacts the experimental program at various rare isotope facilities (such as the NSF supported NSCL and the DOE supported FRIB facilities) that carry out deuteron induced reaction as part of their scientific programs. It also can impact other fields such as quantum chemistry where three-body problems with charged particles are relevant.
